### 3.3.1. Worms, Viruses, and Trojans {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__worms_viruses_and_trojans}
Worms are self-propagating programs that spread without user interaction. Their code is typically stored within an

independent object, such as a hidden executable file. Worms often do not severely damage their host, as they are

concerned with rapid, exponential spreading.

::::: example

::: example-title

Stuxnet

:::

::: example-content

Stuxnet was a 2010 worm that specifically targeted Iranian nuclear facilities. The worm used an unprecedented four

zero-day attacks and was designed to spread via USB flash drives and Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs). In this way it

didn't just rely on networks to propagate. Ultimately Stuxnet's payload targeted the code used to program PLC devices

that control motors and make them spin too fast, destroying the centrifuges. Stuxnet also employed an impressive rootkit

to cover its tracks. Given the level of sophistication Stuxnet is believed to have been developed by the US and Israel.

:::

:::::

Viruses typically require user interaction, such as copying and infected file from one machine to another, and store

their code inside another file on a machine. An executable file may be infected by having the virus code added a

separate page that executes before the standard program code. Viruses can be quite damaging to the host as they may take

significant resources to spread locally. The term virus is also an unfortunately overloaded one. Due to it's popularity

it is often used by some lower-skill threat actors to refer to many different types of malware.

::::: example

::: example-title

Concept Virus

:::

::: example-content

The Concept virus was the first example of a Microsoft Word macro virus. The virus hid itself inside Microsoft Word

files and used Word's embedded macro language to perform its replication tasks. Viruses were later created for Excel and

other programs that had sufficiently sophisticated yet ultimately insecure internal scripting languages.

:::

:::::

A trojan is a form of malware that disguises itself as legitimate software. It does not have to rely on a software

exploit as much as it exploits users into installing, running, or giving extra privileges to the malicious code. Trojans

are the most popular kind of malware as they can be used as an attack vector for many other payloads. The name comes

from Greek mythology, where a Trojan horse was disguised as a gift and given to a besieged town. Within the large horse

were secret troops who came out in the middle of the night and opened the town gates.

::::: example

::: example-title

Emotet

:::

::: example-content

Emotet is a banking trojan from 2014 that spread through emails. It made use of malicious links or macro-enabled

documents to make the user download its code. Emotet has been one of the most costly and destructive pieces of malware

currently averaging about one million in incident remediation. It continues to be adapted to avoid detection and make

use of even more sophisticated malware.

:::

:::::

::::::::::::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.2. Ransomware"}
topic: Describe the fundamental difference in propagation mechanisms between worms and viruses, citing specific examples from the text.
question: Considering the distinct propagation mechanisms of worms and viruses as detailed in the text, what fundamental operational difference dictates Stuxnet's (as presented in the example) ability to achieve exponential spread, a characteristic fundamentally absent in the behavior of a typical virus?

choices.A: Stuxnet’s reliance on USB flash drives allows for direct, rapid dissemination to multiple systems, bypassing the need for network propagation.
choices.B: Stuxnet's use of Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs) enables it to directly manipulate host systems, facilitating autonomous replication independent of user interaction.
choices.C: Viruses require user interaction to execute, limiting their propagation speed to the rate of user actions.
choices.D: Worms are inherently more destructive than viruses, prioritizing rapid spread over minimizing host damage.

explanation: The text states that Stuxnet spread via RPCs, which directly manipulate host systems, enabling autonomous propagation without user intervention—a key distinction from viruses, which require user actions.

## 10.5. Lab: Malicious Containers {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__lab_malicious_containers} While containers have made it much easier to deploy software, they have also made it easier to deploy *malicious* software. Imagine that we have an internal company website, written in PHP and deployed in a Docker container. Given the layered nature of the Docker build system, this application is *trusting* that the images it is building from are secure. Take a look at the following `Dockerfile`{.literal} to see just how easy it is to slip something malicious into the image: `shell.php`{.literal} is a shell written in PHP that will execute with the permissions of the web server. This means it will be able to read and write (but not overwrite) in the /var/www/html directory. Let's download, build, and run this image. Download [the malicious.zip file](https://github.com/rxt1077/it230/raw/main/labs/malicious.zip){.link}, unzip it in a directory where you have write access, and navigate to that directory in your shell. ::: callout-list 1. *①* Build the image and tag it `malicious`{.literal}, don't foget the `.`{.literal} at the end! 2. *②* Run the `malicious`{.literal} image and forward local port 8080 to port 80 in the container ::: Now you should be able to navigate to [http://localhost:8080](http://localhost:8080){.link} to see the default web page.
::: content What's for lunch? :::
Now based on the information in the Dockerfile, get a shell on the compromised web server.
::: content Notice of the time off request on the main page doesn't work? From your shell, create a new web page on the server named `timeoff.html`{.literal} with the text `GRANTED`{.literal}. What command did you use to make the new file? What happens now when you click on the time off link? :::
:::::: :::: {.section .sect2 title="10.6. Review Questions"}

choices.A: `docker exec -it malicious touch /var/www/html/timeoff.html` resulting in a 404 error.
choices.B: `docker exec -it malicious echo "GRANTED" > /var/www/html/timeoff.html` resulting in immediate access to the "GRANTED" page.
choices.C: `docker exec -it malicious cat > /var/www/html/timeoff.html` resulting in a redirect to the `shell.php` script.
choices.D: `docker exec -it malicious wget http://localhost:8080/timeoff.html` resulting in a successful download of the file.

Cryptojacking {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cryptojacking} Crypto currencies utilizing proof-of-work algorithms have made it easier than ever for programs to convert processor cycles into money. Certain types of malware capitalize on this by mining cryptocurrency in the background on a users machine. This theft of power and resources can result income for the malware distributor when the funds from mining are deposited into their online wallet. Cryptojacking is more popular than ever, especially considering that large botnets of infected machines have already been created. Cryptojacking creates a simpler path to monetization for malicious actors who may already have control of many compromised machines. ::: :::::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.5. Rootkit"} ### 3.3.5. Rootkit {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__rootkit} :::: float-group A rootkit is a secret program designed to give back door access to a system. They are designed to remain hidden and may even actively disable or circumvent security software. Due to their low-level nature, many rootkits can be difficult to detect and even more difficult to remove. Rootkits are often classified in accordance with the layer in which they are hidden: ::: description-list [Firmware Rootkit]{.term} : [Firmware is code that a hardware device uses to run. It is often a thin layer of commands used for setting up and interfacing with the device. A firmware rootkit may reside in the BIOS of a motherboard and can be very difficult to remove.]{.principal} [Bootloader Rootkit]{.term} : [A bootloader prepares the system to boot an operating system kernel, typically by loading the kernel into memory. A bootloader rootkit may hijack this process to load itself into separate memory space or manipulate the kernel being loaded.]{.principal} [Kernel-mode Rootkit]{.term} : [Many operating system kernel, including Linux, have the ability to load dynamic modules. These kernel modules have complete access to OS kernel operations. A kernel-mode rootkit can be difficult to detect live as the OS kernel being given the instructions to detect the rootkit can no longer be trusted.]{.principal} [Application Rootkit]{.term} : [An application or user-mode rootkit is usually installed as an application that runs in the background with administrative privileges. These rootkits are typically the easiest to develop and deploy, a low-level knowledge of the hardware the system is using is not required, but they are also the easiest to detect and remove.]{.principal} ::: ::::
topic: The difficulty associated with detecting and removing rootkits, highlighting their low-level nature.
question: Considering the described classifications of rootkits (firmware, bootloader, kernel, and application), which of the following best explains the primary reason for the increased difficulty in removing a firmware rootkit compared to an application rootkit?

choices.A: Firmware rootkits are inherently more complex to detect due to their reliance on specialized hardware interfaces.
choices.B: Firmware rootkits operate at a lower level of the operating system, making them less susceptible to traditional security software detection mechanisms.
choices.C: Application rootkits are more actively concealed by malicious actors, utilizing sophisticated obfuscation techniques.
choices.D: Bootloader rootkits require specialized debugging tools that are rarely available to security analysts.

explanation: The correct answer is B. The text explicitly states that firmware rootkits reside in the BIOS, a very low-level component, and are “very difficult to remove.” This reflects their operating level and the inherent challenges in detecting and eradicating them. Option A is incorrect because it suggests a technical complexity not directly addressed in the text. Option C is irrelevant to the core difficulty. Option D is a distraction.

## 6.3. Network Solutions {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__network_solutions}
Many products are available for handling network traffic. They are typically marketed as either stand-alone devices,

software to install on internal devices, or a subscription service that routes traffic through an external appliance. In

the age of cloud computing network security as a service is becoming increasingly popular.

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.1. Firewall"}


### 6.3.1. Firewall {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__firewall}
A firewall is a service/software/device that blocks unwanted traffic and permits wanted traffic. Typically a firewall is

a barrier between and private network and the Internet.

Software like [nftables](https://wiki.nftables.org/wiki-nftables/index.php/Main_Page){.link} can be used to build a

firewall on a Linux router for many interior clients. Interior clients may also run host-based firewalls such as

[Windows Defender

Firewall](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/windows-firewall/windows-firewall-with-advanced-security){.link}.

Finally hardware solutions for plug-in firewall devices are available from many vendors including Palo Alto and Cisco.

Any combination of these solutions may be used.

Firewalls typically employ rules regarding which packets can come in and how to handle them. For example a firewall may

have a rule to `ALLOW`{.literal} packets from exterior hosts connecting on port 22. This would allow SSH connections.

Likewise a firewall may have a rule to track internal to external connection requests and perform network address

translation (NAT). On an IPv4 network it is common to have a firewall also perform NAT.

Next-Gen Firewalls (NGFW) perform the same functions of a standard firewall, but also employ an integrated intrusion

prevention system (IPS) to mitigate threats. The firewall is a perfect place to perform these actions as it can easily

close of connections. NGFW often tout artificial intelligence threat monitoring and automatic threat intelligence

updating (typically updating attack signatures). A NGFW can also easily be built on a Linux device by making use of [an

IPS](https://www.snort.org/){.link} in conjunction with a netfilter firewall.

Network infrastructure may also make use of a special space *outside* of a firewall called the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ).

Servers that need to be directly connected to the Internet are often put in the DMZ so they don't have a deal with

restrictive firewall rules. These servers may be used to detect malicious activity, monitor incoming traffic, or to

handle basic requests such as serving static web pages.

The largest firewall in the world is the Chinese Great Firewall, started in 1998 as a way to prevent outside influence

in China. It is a system used to block IPs, hijack DNS queries, throttle traffic, and perform MitM decryption. The Great

Firewall is made of proxies and firewalls performing packet-inspection and content filtering. VPNs are often employed

within China to circumvent the great firewall and the great firewall is continually updated to attempt to detect and

shut down this traffic.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.2. Proxy"}
topic: Software firewalls, such as nftables and Windows Defender Firewall, can be deployed on internal devices to create barriers against unwanted network traffic.
question: A network administrator is implementing a security strategy for a Linux router with multiple internal clients. Considering the described capabilities of nftables, what is the *most* critical initial rule to implement to ensure secure SSH access for authorized users?

choices.A: A rule to block all incoming traffic on port 22.
choices.B: A rule to allow all incoming traffic on port 22 from any source IP address.
choices.C: A rule to allow incoming traffic on port 22 specifically from the router's internal network.
choices.D: A rule to log all attempts to connect on port 22, regardless of source.

explanation: The correct answer is C. The context states that a firewall may have a rule to `ALLOW` packets from exterior hosts connecting on port 22, implying a specific internal network source is required for SSH access. Options A and B are overly restrictive, while option D only logs attempts, not allows access.

## Golden Ticket
::: content

A dangerous attack against Kerberos authentication exists and goes by the name *Golden Ticket*. TGTs are the cornerstone

of Kerberos security and the Golden Ticket exploit targets them specifically.

Using the fully qualified domain name, security identifier, username of an account, and a KRBTGT password hash an

attacker can create their own TGTs that will grant access to services. The KRBTGT account is an account that Windows

machines use to perform Kerberos administrative tasks. The KRBTGT password hash can be obtained from any machine where

that account was used if the attacker has complete access to the files on the hard drive. This may be done with physical

access or through the use of malware on a victim machine.

An attacker will only be able to forge TGTs until the KRBTGT account password is changed, [so a common remediation

strategy is to change the

password](https://blog.quest.com/what-is-krbtgt-and-why-should-you-change-the-password/){.link}. Ultimately the

administrator will need to determine how the KRBTGT password hash was obtained in the first place.

:::

</aside>

:::::

::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.11. Tokenization"}
topic: The *Golden Ticket* attack leverages TGTs and KRBTGT passwords to impersonate legitimate users within a Kerberos environment.
question: An attacker successfully leverages a Golden Ticket attack. Which of the following represents the most critical immediate consequence for the targeted network?

choices.A: Increased network bandwidth utilization due to unauthorized service access.
choices.B: Immediate and widespread compromise of all Kerberos-authenticated services.
choices.C: A temporary disruption of Kerberos authentication, requiring a password reset of all user accounts.
choices.D: Enhanced security posture due to the detection of unauthorized activity.

explanation: The correct answer is C. The text explicitly states that forged TGTs remain valid until the KRBTGT password is changed, implying a widespread compromise of Kerberos-authenticated services. Options A, B, and D are incorrect as they describe unrelated consequences.

### 6.3.3. Load Balancer {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__load_balancer}
A common application for reverse proxies is to act as a load balancer for traffic. Load balancers distribute work, in

the form of external client requests, among the internal resources, typically servers.

For example, if a company has four servers supporting a web application, they may employ a reverse proxy load balancer

that takes requests from clients and passes that request to one of the four internal servers. Different metrics are used

to determine how the servers are utilized including least used (round robin), weighted, least amount of active

connections. Load balancers optimize bandwidth and increase availability.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.4. VPN"}


### 6.3.4. VPN {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__vpn}
A virtual private network (VPN) is used to encrypt internet traffic between two networks or a client and a network. VPNs

have become standard procedure for linking remote offices or connecting remote workers. Given the growth of working from

home, almost all users have become familiar with what a VPN is and what it does.

Site-to-site VPNs are typically used for linking offices together. This kind of VPN is on permanently. An example would

be linking two college campuses: NJIT Newark and NJIT Jersey City. In this scenario users on either campus expect to be

able to connect securely to services on the opposite campus at all times. The traffic is encrypted and carried over the

Internet.

Remote access VPNs are used by individuals connecting in to a secure network. This kind of VPN is usually stated through

a application such as Cisco AnyConnect. When the application is running the user is able to securely access internal

resources as if they were at the office.

Many vendors offer VPN products including Cisco, Citrix, Fortinet, Palo Alto, and Checkpoint. Many open source options

also exist for building VPNs including [OpenVPN](https://openvpn.net/){.link},

[WireGuard](https://www.wireguard.com/){.link}, and

[IPsec](https://linuxhint.com/how-to-implement-ipsec-in-linux/){.link}.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.5. TAP"}
topic: Different metrics, such as least used servers or weighted distribution, are employed by load balancers to determine traffic allocation among internal resources.
question: Considering the stated load balancing metrics – least used, weighted, and least amount of active connections – which approach would likely result in the most uneven distribution of traffic across servers if the application exhibits significant bursts of demand during specific periods?

choices.A: Least Used (Round Robin)
choices.B: Weighted
choices.C: Least Amount of Active Connections
choices.D: A combination of Weighted and Least Amount of Active Connections

explanation: Least Used (Round Robin) distributes traffic equally, regardless of server load. Weighted distributes traffic proportionally to server capacity, which may not mitigate the impact of bursts. Least Amount of Active Connections focuses on current load, not anticipated demand. A combination of Weighted and Least Amount of Active Connections is the most likely to adapt to fluctuating demand.

### 7.3.2. Privileged Identity Management (PIM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__privileged_identity_management_pim}
Privileged Identity Management (PIM) is a method of managing access to resources such as locations, commands, audit

reports, and services. PIM aims to provide more granular access control. By recording more information about access it

allows for better reporting regarding suspicious behavior and anomalies. PIM is used in the Windows operating system and

for many Microsoft Azure services.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.3. Privileged Access Management (PAM)"}


### 7.3.3. Privileged Access Management (PAM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__privileged_access_management_pam}
Privileged Access Management (PAM) is a framework for safeguarding identities with advanced capabilities, such as

superusers in a \*NIX system. PAM is common in the Linux world, where it is used to control how administrators log in.

PAM supports many more features than the older \"become root and perform admin tasks\" model. With PAM passwords can be

set to expire, better auditing can be put in place, and privilege escalation can be made temporary.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.4. Identity and Access Management (IAM)"}
topic: IAM is presented as a general concept encompassing the management of identities and access, with PIM and PAM as specific implementations.
question: Considering the descriptions provided, which of the following best differentiates Privileged Access Management (PAM) from Privileged Identity Management (PIM)?

choices.A: PAM focuses exclusively on controlling access to locations, while PIM manages access to commands and audit reports.
choices.B: PAM utilizes temporary privilege escalation and enhanced auditing, while PIM is primarily implemented in the Windows operating system.
choices.C: PIM provides more granular access control than PAM, and PAM is commonly used in the Linux world.
choices.D: IAM encompasses both PIM and PAM, representing a broader framework for managing identities and access.

explanation: The correct answer is B. The text explicitly states that PAM “supports many more features than the older ‘become root and perform admin tasks’ model,” including temporary privilege escalation and enhanced auditing. PIM is noted as being implemented in Windows and Microsoft Azure services.

topic: MAC address spoofing allows an attacker to impersonate a legitimate device, potentially gaining unauthorized access to a network or system.
question: Considering the potential for MAC address spoofing to compromise network security, what is the primary operational consequence of successfully impersonating a legitimate device?

choices.A: Obtaining a temporary denial-of-service condition.
choices.B: Establishing a persistent, unauthorized connection to the network.
choices.C: Executing arbitrary commands on the compromised device.
choices.D: Modifying firewall rules to allow inbound traffic.

context: ### 7.3.9. Single Sign On (SSO) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__single_sign_on_sso} Given the ubiquitous nature of web applications, maintaining separate usernames and passwords can be difficult for users. A recent trend has been to support Single Sign On, where one identity provider is used to confirm that users are who they claim to be. There are a few protocols that make this possible, including SAML and OAuth. SAML stands for Security Assertion Markup Language and is an XML based Single Sign On solution. The SAML workflow centers around the SAML identity provider or IDP. The following steps take place to grant access to a resource via SAML: ::: {.ordered-list .arabic} 1. [User accesses a sevice]{.principal} 2. [User is redirected to SAML IDP with SAML request]{.principal} 3. [User logs in]{.principal} 4. [Credentials are verified]{.principal} 5. [SAML IDP sends credentials to the service]{.principal} ::: OpenID is another protocol that allows users to authenticated using a third-party identity provider in a similar fashion to SAML. One of the main differences is that OpenID was designed to be decentralized, allowing for multiple IDPs for users to choose from. In February 2014 OpenID introduced OpenID Connect (OIDC), a more modern system that allows IDPs to provide information about users via a REST API. This move was largely in response to the popularity of OAuth. OAuth is a method for allowing websites to access parts of a user's profile with the user's permission. OAuth is not *technically* a full-fledged authentication protocol, but it is often used as part of one. ## Sony Rootkit
::: content

In 2005 Sony released CDs for their music software with an application rootkit designed to run on Microsoft Windows

systems. The rootkit ran persistently in the background, slowing systems, and did not have an uninstaller to remove the

program. It was designed to prevent the OS from copying information from audio CDs, but it also opened up several

security holes that could be exploited by other malware. Ultimately the rootkit led to several class-action lawsuits

against Sony BMG and a led to a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission that required Sony to reimburse customers

who reported damages from the rootkit.

:::

### 3.3.6. Botnet {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__botnet}
A botnet is a network of exploited hosts controlled by a single party. These hosts may be desktop computers, servers, or

even internet of things (IoT) devices. Botnets are often used in large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS)

attacks where the nature of the attack is to have many machines flooding a single machine with traffic. Botnets may also

be used to send spam emails as their access to SMTP email relay may vary depending on their internet service provider

(ISP).

Bots are typically controlled through a command and control (C2, C&C) server. While this C2 server may use a custom

protocol, it is far more typical for modern botnets to rely on other infrastructure. C2 traffic can use SSH, HTTP,

Internet Relay Chat (IRC), or even Discord to send commands to bots and receive data from bots.

:::

Lab: Exploiting log4j {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__lab_exploiting_log4j} In this lab we will examine the log4j vulnerability, [CVE-2021-44228](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44228){.link}. This vulnerability takes advantage of a flaw in a common logging library used by many Java applications, including Apache, neo4j, Steam, iCloud, and Minecraft. Any attacker that can cause a message to be logged can use the Java Naming and Directory Interface (JNDI) and cause the target to reach out to another server, LDAP in our example, and load a remote Java class file. This file can contain any code that the attacker wishes to inject into the server process.
::: content Do some research: What versions of log4j are affected by this vulnerability? :::
This lab uses a Docker Compose configuration to simulate a network with an attacker and a target. The target runs a [known-vulnerable, example application](https://github.com/leonjza/log4jpwn){.link} written by leonjza. This example application logs the `User-Agent`{.literal} header, request path, and a query string parameter of a request as seen below:
::: content What port does our vulnerable app run on? :::
Our attacker container has [the `pwn.py`{.literal} script](https://github.com/leonjza/log4jpwn/blob/master/pwn.py){.link}, also by leonjza, which does two things: ::: {.ordered-list .arabic} 1. [Runs a fake LDAP server in the background on port 8888]{.principal} 2. [Sends a request with the JNDI URI referencing the fake LDAP server asking for a Java value to leak]{.principal} 3. [Parses and prints the response]{.principal} ::: Using this setup we can show how log4j can be used to leak sensitive information from running processes. We will use it to leak the value of the environment variable `DB_PASSWORD`{.literal}. As it isn't uncommon to store secrets in environment variables on running containers, this should suffice to see just how devastating this exploit can be. Start by downloading [the zip archive of this lab](https://github.com/rxt1077/it230/blob/main/labs/log4j.zip?raw=true){.link} and unzipping it in a directory where you have write permissions and can navigate to in a terminal application. Once you've done that, you can bring the lab up by typing `docker-compose up`{.literal} in that directory. Output should look similar to what you see below: You'll notice that the `target`{.literal} service is up and running the `log4jpwn`{.literal} example application and that its output goes straight to the screen. The `attacker`{.literal} service will exit immediately as it is meant for interactive use and doesn't run anything in the background. In another terminal, navigate to the lab directory again and run `docker-compose run attacker bash`{.literal}. This will be the shell that you use to attack the target: ::: callout-list 1. *①* Notice how the prompt changes once we are in the container ::: In the attack shell, use the `ip`{.literal} command to determine the IPv4 address of your container. We will need this since the `attacker`{.literal} container will be listening for connections from `target`{.literal} once the exploit string is logged. ::: callout-list 1. *①* You're IP is *not* ``{.literal} it is whatever you find in its place! ::: Once you have the IP address, you can run the `pwn.py`{.literal} script on the `attacker`{.literal} container and you should be able to read the `DB_PASSWORD`{.literal} environment variable on the `target`{.literal} container. ::: callout-list 1. *①* Docker Compose will resolve service names to IP addresses so the target URI doesn't require finding an IP 2. *②* The value of `DB_PASSWORD`{.literal} can will be here. :::
::: content What is the database password? :::
